comment.author: 10248165@N00
comment._content: Pioneering since 1913 Margaret Sanger's fame became worldwide in 1927, when she helped organize and spoke before the first World Population Conference at Geneva, Switzerland. She and her follower continued to lobby for freer state and Federal laws on contraception and for the dissemination of birth control knowledge through welfare programs. By 1940 the American birth control movement was operating a thriving clinic program and enjoying general acceptance by the medical profession and an increasingly favorable public attitude. renaissance is a fanatic

comment.author: 87622920@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/jeannelorie] satan is a created being who has fallen from grace, an angel who is allowed to exist for a season. 

And in the words of Uncle Joe, who said it best: satan is finite. God is infinite.

God creates.
satan destroys.

God needs nothing in order to act.
satan depends on God, without whom satan can do nothing.

Among satan's lies is the false claim that he is "equal but opposite" to God.
The claim is not only false, but flatly absurd.

There can be no equal but opposite force to He who is infinite.

God and satan surely are not the same being.

God is the sole genuine creator of anything that ever was, is, or will be.

At his most powerful, satan can damage or possibly destroy things, but he can create nothing.

comment.author: 37149688@N08
comment._content: The sad truth is that this woman was a pioneer in the theory of eugenics and the murder of "imbeciles", as a means of perfecting the human population. Well, I've known more than a few "imbeciles" who are decent people and often better souls than the best educated and wealthy elite. Who contributes more to society? The former always seem to bring a needed sense of joy and reminder of the sensitivity and fragility of life. My opinion and experience. I won't even touch the topic of abortion or God (I am a "fan" of God). This really isn't the place.

comment._content: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Margaret_Sanger Wilipedia actually as a pretty good summary of her bio and positions. She specifically opposed euthanasia all the time and abortion in most cases. She believed that birth control was the cure for abortions. It's a wonderful portrait. Thanks for posting it.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: In May, 1914, when this photo appeared in the Bain News Agency's photostream, Margaret Sanger had begun publishing her first magazine advocating birth control (in opposition to the idiotic Comstock laws). After four issues, it was suppressed by the U. S. government.
